texts.definition: Information and access to game actions that are presented in computer games as if they were on a plane in front of the presentation of the game world.
markups: <style="Definition">Information and access to game actions that are presented in computer games as if they were on a plane in front of the presentation of the game world.</style>

Computer games that have game worlds present these to players through user interfaces. However, often additional information is presented to players as on a plane right before the actual presentation of the game world. Such presentations of information and access to gameplay actions are called <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style>.

Note: ''this pattern describes a more generic design solution that a true HUD interface. It is more aligned to the ''Overlay'' part in Fagerholt & Lorentzon's conceptual view of visual UI conventions in FPS games<ref name="fagerholt"/>.

True <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> are used in games with first person views, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%20series">Half-Life</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>. However, the idea of overlaying information in a plane in front of a game world presentation exists also in computer-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> shows how game series that first used third-person views and later first-person views can continuously make use of <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style>.

While many different types of information can be presented in <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>, the creation of <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style> in a game instantiates a (at least minimal) <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interface</style> by its very nature, and affects <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions directly. While <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> can serve as reminders of <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> accessible in other places, <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> can also be the only source for them and can thereby both modulate and instantiate them. <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> can also be used to simple actions, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style>.
<style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> can optionally be used to change what is shown in <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> if these are used in a game.

While <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Screen%20Splatter">Screen Splatter</link></style> can be seen as its own plane which information is presented on, it is equally possible to view it as a way of modifying what is presented on <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> can maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> if the game uses <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and it makes sense for players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> to have these. This of course also requires that no <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> are represented through the interfaces though.

<style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> is an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style>. While <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> make most diegetic sense in games with <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style>, the use of the term here to signify any information in an overlay to the diegetic presentation of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> means that it can equally well be used in games with <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person Views</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="god-views">God Views</link></style> (as the examples from the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> show).

The use of <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> provides a clear way of presenting <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> in games. When they don't break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> they can also ensure <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. The presences of very minimalistic <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style>, for example those only showing <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, can be enough to make players aware that they are playing <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> in a game.

As stated above, while <style="CurrentLink">HUD Interfaces</style> can be diegetic in their presentation, they often introduce <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>) and thereby work against <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>
